intro: Chloraea biserialis, commonly known as the twin-rowed greenbrier, is a flowering plant native to eastern Australia. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its climbing habit and dense, thorny stems. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers arranged in pairs along the stems, giving it its specific epithet "biserialis." Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often covered with fine hairs. Chloraea biserialis is typically found in moist, shaded habitats such as rainforests and along stream banks.
